qas.question: According to Popper, what is not grounds for doubt?
What principle of traditional philosophy did Popper take an anti-justificationist stance against?
What does Popper believe is essential to do to theories instead of justification?
What don't we need to look for about theories in Popper's view?
What did Popper think needed to be justified?
What is a justification for doubt?
Who believed that good positive reasons exist?
What did Popper think should never be tested or scrutinized?

context: To <b4_0><b7_0>Popper<b7_0/><b4_0/>, who was an anti-justificationist, traditional philosophy is misled by the false <a1_0>principle of sufficient reason<a1_0/>. He thinks that no <b5_0>assumption<b5_0/> can ever be or needs ever to be justified, so <b6_0>a <a0_0>lack of justification<b6_0/><a0_0/> is not a justification for doubt. Instead, <b8_0>theories<b8_0/> should be tested and scrutinised. It is not the goal to bless theories with claims of certainty or justification, but to <a2_0>eliminate errors<a2_0/> in them. He writes, "there are no such things as <a3_0>good positive reasons<a3_0/>; nor do we need such things [...] But [philosophers] obviously cannot quite bring [themselves] to believe that this is my opinion, let alone that it is right" (The Philosophy of Karl Popper, p. 1043)
